Award.AwardTitle: Strategies: SISTERS: Sustaining Interest in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Research in Society

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The SISTERS project reinforces the school curriculum through a theory-driven, after- school science and engineering education program for girls in grades 5 and 6 from low income communities. The girls are engaged in science and engineering lessons with technology-rich, hands-on experiences which foster critical thinking, and engineering practices. They discover and come to appreciate the iterative research process and learn the proper use of technological resources which builds their confidence in pursuing future STEM learning and careers. Each year, eight specially selected formal and informal educators from four schools in the Encinitas School district and eight female undergraduate engineering students from the University of California at San Diego lead twice-weekly after school science classes for about 100 girls focusing on solving socially relevant problems in solar energy and energy efficacy. Other activities include twice yearly field trips, twice yearly family science events, meetings with female professionals and a capstone team challenge project. A week-long professional development for the instructors and undergraduate students is offered for them to modify and use the lessons and to integrate environmental sensors. This project represents a strategic partnership between a nationally engaged research university and a local school district to create an innovative pilot program that can serve as a scalable and replicable model for others to follow.

The project studies how the interaction with role models and the use of socially relevant scientific and engineering challenges impact fifth and sixth grade girls' self-efficacy, STEM content and their interest in STEM Careers. The evaluation also measures teachers' change in practice. Information is gathered through surveys, focus groups and observations. Validated assessments developed with some of the activities being used are used to measure student knowledge of engineering practices and science concepts. The project intervenes at a critical time in student development of self-efficacy in STEM subjects. The students develop relationships with positive role models that foster a continued interest in science and mathematics and STEM careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SISTERS (http://www.ucsdsisters.org) was an innovative three-year strategy project to create and study a theory-driven and technology-rich after-school science education intervention for fifth- and sixth-grade girls.  Each academic year, girls from four elementary schools participated in twenty weeks of twice-weekly science and engineering ?adventures,? facilitated by specially selected and trained informal science educators and undergraduate mentors with STEM majors.  (In the final year of the project, the program was expanded to include girls from a fifth elementary school.)  Modules of adventures culminated in design challenges in which the girls worked in teams to design and build a solution to a socially urgent problem, such as water pollution, the need for alternative energy, etc.  The girls then demonstrated their solutions to family and friends at twice-yearly Design Showcases.  Moreover, each year girls were able to participate in field trips to the local zoo, safari park, aquarium, etc.  

 Over the course of three years, SISTERS enrolled 297 girls, 24% of the eligible fifth- and sixth-grade girls in the school district.  The percentage of SISTERS participants who identified as Hispanic (34%) was slightly higher than the percentage of Hispanic girls who were eligible for the program (32%).  

 The majority of girls who joined SISTERS stayed in the program (77%).  Moreover, girls attended 85% of the sessions.  

 Three outcome variables were investigated in relation to the SISTERS program each year: 1) self-confidence and expectations for success in STEM (Confidence); 2) interest in STEM subjects and activities (Curiosity); and 3) understanding of and interest in science, engineering and careers in these fields (Attitudes).  Across the three years, one positive effect was found in terms of these variables. Girls who participated in the SISTERS program demonstrated a marginally significant increase in their attitudes toward engineering.  

 Scales to measure two aspects of the SISTERS program were added in the second year of the project, including a measure of mindset (Dweck, 2007) and an adapted version of the School Connection Scale (Brown, 1999; Brown & Evans, 2002).  Mindset results varied from Year 2 to Year 3; results were flat in the second year and significantly increased in the third.  In Year 3, average mindset scores increased from 4.42 out of 6 at baseline to 4.65 by the end of the school year.  

 Year 2 and 3 results revealed that SISTERS participants experienced high levels of connection to the program. Indeed, in Year 3,  91% of the SISTERS girls reported feeling connected to the program, indicated by average ratings that were on the positive side of the scale (i.e., in the ?agree? to ?strongly agree? range).  

 To gain a clearer understanding of connection, SISTERS girls were interviewed mid-way through the final year of the project.  Using the think-aloud method, girls were asked to explain their ratings for a subset of items from the connection scale, both in relation to school and in relation to SISTERS.  Regardless of whether they were new to SISTERS or were participating for a second year, girls? ratings for their school and for SISTERS were similar and high (3.34 and 3.36 out of 4, respectively).  Girls felt connected to both school and SISTERS because they have friends, they can be a success in both contexts, and there is racial equality.  Girls believed that the culture of SISTERS was inclusive of all girls, which was contrasted with the way that students tend to interact with only the same group of friends during the school day.  SISTERS was also described as more flexible in that girls were free to chat about things other than the day?s ?adventure? as long as they completed the activity.  Moreover, the girls shared that they felt more comfortable speaking up because they understood that making mistakes was just part of the process.  

 In the second and third years of the project, a final series of analyses focused on the relationship between SISTERS attendance and connection, and post-program outcomes.  Not surprisingly, SISTERS attendance was positively correlated to girls? connection to the program.  Moreover, attendance was correlated with three of four measures (Confidence, Curiosity, and Attitudes).  Mindset scores and attendance were not correlated.  SISTERS connection scores mimicked this pattern, with significant positive correlations with three of the four outcome measures (Confidence, Curiosity, and Attitudes).  Mindset scores and connection were not correlated.

 Perhaps most importantly, it was found that SISTERS connection scores predicted post-program outcomes above and beyond girls? initial scores on the measures for Confidence, Curiosity, and Attitudes.

 Brown, R. A. (1999).  The influence of extracurricular activity participation upon youth problem behavior: School connection as a mediator(doctoral dissertation).  Retrieved from ERIC.

 Brown, R., & Evans, W. P. (2002).  Extracurricular activity and ethnicity: Creating greater school connection among diverse student populations.  Urban Education, 37(1), pp. 41-58.

 Dweck, C. S. (2007).  Mindset: The new psychology of success.  New York: Random House.
